metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, PHP, Python, Bootstrap, Java and XML.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: C Pointers and Arrays
Pointers & Arrays
You can also use pointers to access arrays .
content.html: You can also use pointers to access arrays.

content.text: Consider the following array of integers:
content.html: Consider the following array of integers:

content.code_html: int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};

content.text: You learned from the arrays chapter that you can loop through the array elements with a for loop:
content.html: You learned from the arrays chapter that you can loop through the array elements with a for loop:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};int i;for (i = 0; i < 4; 
    i++) {  printf("%d\n", myNumbers[i]);}

content.code:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};int i;for (i = 0; i < 4;
i++) {  printf("%d\n", myNumbers[i]);}

syntax_highlighting.text:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};int i;for (i = 0; i < 4; 
    i++) {  printf("%d\n", myNumbers[i]);}

content.code_html:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};
int i;

for (i = 0; i < 4; i++) {
  printf("%d\n", myNumbers[i]);
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};int i;for (i = 0; i < 4; 
    i++) {  printf("%d\n", myNumbers[i]);}

content.text: Instead of printing the value of each array element, let's print the memory address of each array element:
content.html: Instead of printing the value of each array element, let's print the memory address of each array element:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};int i;for (i = 0; i < 4; 
    i++) {  printf("%p\n", &myNumbers[i]);}

content.code:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};int i;for (i = 0; i < 4;
i++) {  printf("%p\n", &myNumbers[i]);}

syntax_highlighting.text:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};int i;for (i = 0; i < 4; 
    i++) {  printf("%p\n", &myNumbers[i]);}

content.code_html:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};
int i;

for (i = 0; i < 4; i++) {
  printf("%p\n", &myNumbers[i]);
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};int i;for (i = 0; i < 4; 
    i++) {  printf("%p\n", &myNumbers[i]);}

content.text: Note that the last number of each of the elements' memory address is different, with an addition of 4.
content.html: Note that the last number of each of the elements' memory address is different, with an addition of 4.

content.text: It is because the size of an int type is typically 4 bytes, remember:
content.html: It is because the size of an int type is typically 4 bytes, remember:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Create an int variableint myInt;// Get the memory size of an int
    printf("%lu", sizeof(myInt));
// Get the memory size of an int

content.code:
// Create an int variableint myInt;// Get the memory size of an int
printf("%lu", sizeof(myInt));

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Create an int variableint myInt;// Get the memory size of an int
    printf("%lu", sizeof(myInt));
// Get the memory size of an int

content.code_html:
// Create an int variable
int myInt;

// Get the memory size of an int
 printf("%lu", sizeof(myInt));

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Create an int variableint myInt;// Get the memory size of an int
    printf("%lu", sizeof(myInt));
// Get the memory size of an int

content.text: So from the "memory address example" above, you can see that the compiler reserves 4 bytes of memory for each array element, which means that the entire array takes up 16 bytes (4 * 4) of memory storage:
content.html: So from the "memory address example" above, you can see that the compiler reserves 4 bytes of memory for each array element, which means that the entire array takes up 16 bytes (4 * 4) of memory storage:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};// Get the size of the myNumbers 
    arrayprintf("%lu", sizeof(myNumbers));

// Get the size of the myNumbers 
    array

content.code:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};// Get the size of the myNumbers
arrayprintf("%lu", sizeof(myNumbers));

syntax_highlighting.text:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};// Get the size of the myNumbers 
    arrayprintf("%lu", sizeof(myNumbers));

// Get the size of the myNumbers 
    array

content.code_html:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};

// Get the size of the myNumbers array
printf("%lu", sizeof(myNumbers));

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};// Get the size of the myNumbers 
    arrayprintf("%lu", sizeof(myNumbers));

// Get the size of the myNumbers 
    array

content.text: How Are Pointers Related to Arrays
Ok, so what's the relationship between pointers and arrays? Well, in C, the name of an array , is actually a pointer to the first element of the array.
content.html: Ok, so what's the relationship between pointers and arrays? Well, in C, the name of an array, is actually a pointer to the first element of the array.

content.text: Confused? Let's try to understand this better, and use our "memory address example" above again.
content.html: Confused? Let's try to understand this better, and use our "memory address example" above again.

content.text: The memory address of the first element is the same as the name of the array :
content.html: The memory address of the first element is the same as the name of the array:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Get the memory address of the 
    myNumbers array

// Get the memory 
    address of the first array element

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Get the memory address of the 
    myNumbers array

// Get the memory 
    address of the first array element

content.code_html:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};

// Get the memory address of the myNumbers array
printf("%p\n", myNumbers);

// Get the memory address of the first array element
printf("%p\n", &myNumbers[0]);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Get the memory address of the 
    myNumbers array

// Get the memory 
    address of the first array element

content.text: This basically means that we can work with arrays through pointers!
content.html: This basically means that we can work with arrays through pointers!

content.text: How? Since myNumbers is a pointer to the first element in myNumbers, you can use the * operator to access it:
content.html: How? Since myNumbers is a pointer to the first element in myNumbers, you can use the * operator to access it:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};// Get the value of the first 
    element in myNumbersprintf("%d", *myNumbers);

// Get the value of the first 
    element in myNumbers

content.code:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};// Get the value of the first
element in myNumbersprintf("%d", *myNumbers);

syntax_highlighting.text:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};// Get the value of the first 
    element in myNumbersprintf("%d", *myNumbers);

// Get the value of the first 
    element in myNumbers

content.code_html:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};

// Get the value of the first element in myNumbers
printf("%d", *myNumbers);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};// Get the value of the first 
    element in myNumbersprintf("%d", *myNumbers);

// Get the value of the first 
    element in myNumbers

content.text: To access the rest of the elements in myNumbers, you can increment the pointer/array (+1, +2, etc):
content.html: To access the rest of the elements in myNumbers, you can increment the pointer/array (+1, +2, etc):

syntaxHighlighting.text:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};// Get the value of the second 
    element in myNumbersprintf("%d\n", *(myNumbers + 1));// Get the value of the 
    third 
    element in myNumbersprintf("%d", *(myNumbers + 2));// 
    and so on..

// Get the value of the second 
    element in myNumbers

content.code:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};// Get the value of the second
element in myNumbersprintf("%d\n", *(myNumbers + 1));// Get the value of the
third
element in myNumbersprintf("%d", *(myNumbers + 2));//
and so on..

syntax_highlighting.text:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};// Get the value of the second 
    element in myNumbersprintf("%d\n", *(myNumbers + 1));// Get the value of the 
    third 
    element in myNumbersprintf("%d", *(myNumbers + 2));// 
    and so on..

// Get the value of the second 
    element in myNumbers

content.code_html:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};

// Get the value of the second element in myNumbers
printf("%d\n", *(myNumbers + 1));

// Get the value of the third element in myNumbers
printf("%d", *(myNumbers + 2));

// and so on..

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};// Get the value of the second 
    element in myNumbersprintf("%d\n", *(myNumbers + 1));// Get the value of the 
    third 
    element in myNumbersprintf("%d", *(myNumbers + 2));// 
    and so on..

// Get the value of the second 
    element in myNumbers

content.text: Or loop through it:
content.html: Or loop through it:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};int *ptr = myNumbers;int i;
    for (i = 0; i < 4; i++) {  printf("%d\n", *(ptr + i));}

content.code:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};int *ptr = myNumbers;int i;
for (i = 0; i < 4; i++) {  printf("%d\n", *(ptr + i));}

syntax_highlighting.text:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};int *ptr = myNumbers;int i;
 for (i = 0; i < 4; i++) {  printf("%d\n", *(ptr + i));}

content.code_html:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};
int *ptr = myNumbers;
int i;

for (i = 0; i < 4; i++) {
  printf("%d\n", *(ptr + i));
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};int *ptr = myNumbers;int i;
    for (i = 0; i < 4; i++) {  printf("%d\n", *(ptr + i));}

content.text: It is also possible to change the value of array elements with pointers:
content.html: It is also possible to change the value of array elements with pointers:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};// Change the 
    value of the first element to 13*myNumbers = 13;// Change the 
    value of the second element to 17*(myNumbers +1) = 17;// Get 
    the value of the first elementprintf("%d\n", *myNumbers);// Get 
    the value of the second elementprintf("%d\n", *(myNumbers + 1));

// Change the 
    value of the first element to 13

// Change the 
    value of the second element to 17

// Get 
    the value of the first element

// Get 
    the value of the second element

content.code:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};// Change the
value of the first element to 13*myNumbers = 13;// Change the
value of the second element to 17*(myNumbers +1) = 17;// Get
the value of the first elementprintf("%d\n", *myNumbers);// Get
the value of the second elementprintf("%d\n", *(myNumbers + 1));

syntax_highlighting.text:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};// Change the 
    value of the first element to 13*myNumbers = 13;// Change the 
    value of the second element to 17*(myNumbers +1) = 17;// Get 
    the value of the first elementprintf("%d\n", *myNumbers);// Get 
    the value of the second elementprintf("%d\n", *(myNumbers + 1));

// Change the 
    value of the first element to 13

// Change the 
    value of the second element to 17

// Get 
    the value of the first element

// Get 
    the value of the second element

content.code_html:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};

// Change the value of the first element to 13
*myNumbers = 13;

// Change the value of the second element to 17
*(myNumbers +1) = 17;

// Get the value of the first element
printf("%d\n", *myNumbers);

// Get the value of the second element
printf("%d\n", *(myNumbers + 1));

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};// Change the 
    value of the first element to 13*myNumbers = 13;// Change the 
    value of the second element to 17*(myNumbers +1) = 17;// Get 
    the value of the first elementprintf("%d\n", *myNumbers);// Get 
    the value of the second elementprintf("%d\n", *(myNumbers + 1));

// Change the 
    value of the first element to 13

// Change the 
    value of the second element to 17

// Get 
    the value of the first element

// Get 
    the value of the second element

content.text: This way of working with arrays might seem a bit excessive. Especially with simple arrays like in the examples above. However, for large arrays, it can be much more efficient to access and manipulate arrays with pointers.
content.html: This way of working with arrays might seem a bit excessive. Especially with simple arrays like in the examples above. However, for large arrays, it can be much more efficient to access and manipulate arrays with pointers.

content.text: It is also considered faster and easier to access two-dimensional arrays with pointers.
content.html: It is also considered faster and easier to access two-dimensional arrays with pointers.

content.text: And since strings are actually arrays, you can also use pointers to access strings .
content.html: And since strings are actually arrays, you can also use pointers to access strings.

content.text: For now, it's great that you know how this works. But like we specified in the previous chapter; pointers must be handled with care , since it is possible to overwrite other data stored in memory.
content.html: For now, it's great that you know how this works. But like we specified in the previous chapter; pointers must be handled with care, since it is possible to overwrite other data stored in memory.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
How would you access the third element in myNumbers using pointers? int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};
content.html:
How would you access the third element in myNumbers using pointers?
int myNumbers[4] = {25, 50, 75, 100};
